definitions.definition: a large piece of a solid material that is square or rectangular in shape and usually has flat sides

examples.text: The houses are made of concrete blocks with tin roofs.
a block of ice/wood
The wall was made from massive blocks of stone.

definitions.definition: a tall building that contains flats or offices; buildings that form part of a school, hospital, etc. which are used for a particular purpose

examples.text: a **block of flats**
a **tower block**
an **office block**
She lives in a modern **apartment block**.
the university’s science block
They live in the next block.
The prisoners had been transferred to a different cell block.

definitions.definition: the length of one side of a piece of land or group of buildings, from the place where one street crosses it to the next

examples.text: His apartment is three blocks away from the police station.
They walked a few blocks down the street.

definitions.definition: a group of buildings with streets on all sides

examples.text: She took the dog for a walk around the block.
The downtown area covers four **city blocks**.
The hotel occupies an entire block.
People were queueing round the block to get in.

definitions.definition: an area of land for building a house on
a quantity of something or an amount of time that is considered as a single unit

examples.text: a block of shares
a block of text in a document
The theatre gives discounts for **block bookings** *(= a large number of tickets bought at the same time)*.
The three-hour class is divided into four blocks of 45 minutes each.

definitions.definition: something that makes movement or progress difficult or impossible

examples.text: Lack of training acts as a block to progress in a career.
I suddenly had a **mental block** and couldn't remember his name.

definitions.definition: a movement that stops another player from going forward
the two blocks on the ground that runners push their feet against at the beginning of a race
(in the past) the piece of wood on which a person’s head was cut off as a punishment
a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave
to be sold, especially at an auction (= a sale in which items are sold to the person who offers the most money)
to have a lot of experience
used to threaten somebody that you will hit them
a person who is new to a place, an organization, etc.

examples.text: Despite his six years in politics, he was still regarded by many as the new kid on the block.

definitions.definition: to risk losing your job, damaging your reputation, etc. by doing or saying something

examples.text: It's not a matter that I'm prepared to put my head on the block for.

wordOrigin: Middle English (denoting a log or tree stump): from Old French bloc (noun), bloquer (verb), from Middle Dutch blok, of unknown ultimate origin.
